name: Kepler-336
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-336 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-336 is a star with 1.694 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.3 times its radius. It is located 7604.46 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-336 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-336 b

Kepler-336 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.02 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-336.

The mass of Kepler-336 b is 1.01 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-336 b is 1.02 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-336 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-336 c

Kepler-336 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 9.60 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-336.

The mass of Kepler-336 c is 5.68 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-336 c is 2.1 that of Earth. At 5.68 Earth masses, Kepler-336 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-336 d

Kepler-336 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 20.68 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-336.

The mass of Kepler-336 d is 7.59 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-336 d is 2.37 that of Earth. At 7.59 Earth masses, Kepler-336 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-336, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
